results.title: Little mut goes flying: plus four other stories
results.creator_credit: Cosgrove Hall Films, Jackie Cockle and Ellen Meske
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “The Animal shelf”.
Five stories are contained on this tape comprising LITTLE MUT GOES FLYING, BABYSITTING FOR MRS MOLE, TIMOTHY’S PET BALLOON, THE TRAIL and THE MODEL MONSTER. LITTLE MUT GOES FLYING: The animals decide to build a see saw- motivated by a trip to the playground. Woeful decides that’s boring and sets off to Bluebell Wood to build a swing. BABYSITTING FOR MRS MOLE: Stripey and Getup babysit the baby moles whilst Mrs Mole is visiting her sick sister. They have their hands full when the babies escape from the summer house. TIMOTHY’S PET BALLOON: The animals start to worry that Timothy doesn’t love them anymore when he tells them that he’s buying a rabbit. An unexpected visitor arrives on the shelf and the animals decide to move into the rabbit hutch. THE TRAIL: The animals become interested in exploration after Timothy reads them a book about explorers. Timothy decides it would be fun if he laid a trail of his own and the animals get a chance to be explorers as they follow the clues Timothy has left them. THE MODEL MONSTER: The animals try their hand at model making after seeing Timothy make a model ship from some old pieces of cardboard and egg boxes.

results.title: Little man - big city
results.creator_credit: MAFILM Pannonia Filmstudio, World Health Organisation, Roman Kunz, Gyula Macskassy and Gyorgy Varnia
results.brief_description: An animated film which dramatises the plight of today’s urban dweller. Shows the city’s relentless assault on the health of its inhabitants. The `little man’ lives in a typical urban centre where poor planning, haphazard design and inadequate health controls have depleted him - emotionally and physically. The film urges united action to make cities healthy and enjoyable places in which to live.

results.title: Little Lord Fauntleroy
results.creator_credit: BBC, Richard Callanan and Andrew Morgan
results.brief_description: Twelve year-old Cedric Erroll’s world is turned upside down when, completely unexpectedly, a lawyer from London arrives with the news that he is the grandson and rightful heir to the vast lands and fortunes of the Earl of Dorincourt. So, Little Lord Fauntleroy and his mother leave their humble New York abode to live in a castle in England. However, he soon finds that money doesn’t necessarily bring happiness. His bitter and often cruel grandfather refuses to allow Cedric’s mother into his home. Starring Michael Benz as Cedric, George Baker of Inspector Wrexford fame as the Earl of Dorincourt and Betsy Brantley as Cedric’s mother. A triumph of good over bad, the new world over the old, this timeless story has captured the hearts of both children and adults alike for generations. Based on the novel by Frances Hodges Burnett.

results.title: Little Lord Fauntleroy
results.creator_credit: David O. Selznick and John Cromwell
results.brief_description: Cedric is a spoilt child brought up in Brooklyn in the 1880’s who inherits an English title and finds his life transformed. In his stately family home in England, Cedric wins over his stern grandfather (C. Aubrey Smith). Freddie Bartholomew stars in the title role and is well supported by Dolores Costello as his mother and Mickey Rooney as the bootblack.

results.title: Little Johnny Jones
results.creator_credit: Group W Cable Productions, Showtime Entertainment, Bill Siegler and Gary Halvorson
results.brief_description: This Goodspeed Opera House production of George M. Cohan’s classic American musical “Little Johnny Jones” is performed on stage in front of a live audience and features such hit songs as “Yankee Doodle Dandy” and “Give my regards to Broadway”. The cast includes Eric Weitz as Johnny Jones and Peter Van Norden as Anthony Anstey, with Lenny Wolpe, Ernie Sabella, Bruce Chew, Jack Bittner, Maureen Brennan, Anna Mcneely, Jane Galloway. Book, music and lyrics by George M. Cohan adapted by Alfred Uhry and stage direction by Gerald Gutierrez.
